description:
Nvidia didn't want reviewers to look at this product until launch - and it's clear there are problems with it. Put the RTX 5060 into a modern system supporting PCIe 4.0 or better and you can get performance that handily beats a PlayStation 5. However, this card is badly balanced - compute power is OK for the budget gamer but the lack of VRAM is problematic and the pared back PCIe interface spells trouble for those on the older system the card is most likely to be used with. Here is Rich's review.

Note: RTX 5060 Ti and RTX 3060 12GB are used in the main benchmark sections. There's a small error in the Forza section - the label reads 5060 Ti, but it is the 5060 benched there.

Eurogamer review with all the numbers: https://www.eurogamer.net/digitalfoundry-2025-nvidia-geforce-rtx-5060-review

Join the DF Supporter Program for pristine video downloads, behind the scenes content, early access to new videos, early access to DF Direct Weekly and much, much more: https://bit.ly/3jEGjvx

Go here to check out DF merch! https://store.digitalfoundry.net

comments.text:
@samgragas8467  Nope, most games just don't need that much VRAM, there's only like 5 games in my Steam Library of 2000 games that are capable of exceeding 8gb of VRAM without going to absurd resolutions like 8K. Older games use a measly 1-3gb VRAM even at high resolutions. 4K Cyberpunk with psycho ray-tracing, max textures, barely exceeds 9gb, even driving through Night City at 200mph. But playing at 1440p gives me like twice the fps, so I usually don't play at 4K, Cyberpunk typically uses about 7gb when I play it. I've tried Elden Ring, Clair Obscur, Oblivion Remastered, Flintlock, Remnant 2, Starfield. Clair Obscur uses 6.5, Oblviion used 7.2gb, 4K max textures.

You pretty much have to choose from specific VRAM titles and run them at unrealistic settings to exceed 8gb VRAM. 8gb VRAM is still good for now, but if you want to future-proof beyond the next 2-3 years, more like 12gb would be good. Most people tend to upgrade every few years, so I don't see the issue with 8gb VRAM right now. None of my friends have more than 8gb VRAM and they are using almost decade old cards to play new games

I bought a 5060 TI 16GB last week and I was surprised to see the PCIE connector on the card had the unused lanes physically removed.
Looks odd especially that the PCB catch that locks the card to the MB is also gone.
So the only thing holding the card in place is the I/O shield.
One other oddity of this card is the 8 Pin power connector is right up against the I/O shield as to not pull the card out by the cable.
At least it was MSRP.
It's the Gigabyte Windforce RTX 5060 TI 16GB if you want to see for yourself.

comments.text: I fell like some of these reviews aren't being honest and they're trying to push a narrative more than honestly review the capabilities of a card. We know that these 8 gb cards often suffer in 1080p games at ultra settings. But how do they perform at low/lowest settings? Without ray tracing. Without upscaling. What does that look like compared to a console? These are basically the lowest or near lowest priced cards you can get and they're geared for lower end systems. DF does have a valid point about the PCIe bandwidth not being enough and they are correct to say that's a poor design choice on Nvidia's part. But the point is while the industry tends to test these GPUs at max everything to show a worst case scenario, we're not seeing the best case scenario and we don't know what that looks like when they only test one way, so we don't know how good they can be either. I wish that reviewers would show that side of it as well. Frank Azor was not wrong when he said that most people game at 1080p and that 8gb IS often enough to provide a smooth experience. Perhaps that comes with the caveat of "when not maxed out" but we don't even know if that's all that bad either. So when we don't get to see that, it's hard for a person to make a fair assessment of a cards overall capability.

"The 3060 is 60% of a 5060" and "The 5060 is 40% faster than a 3060" are not the same thing. If you change the baseline from the 5060 to the 3060 the % difference will change too.
3060: From 60% to 100%
5060: From 100% to X
Cross multiplying:
60x = 100 * 100
x = 100 * 100 / 60 = 166.67%

@Wobbothe3rd Its not that simple though, as effectively both CPU and GPU can access the same copy of the assets in memory whereas a PC needs to have two copies across its split memory system.

So rule of thumb, you need as much VRAM as the console has unified memory and you need more system RAM than you have VRAM, as things need to be loaded into system memory before being pushed to the VRAM - even when using DirectStorage.

comments.text:
Its not shocking only because its been the mainstream narrative for years now while they benchmark the most demanding latest games on a budget entry level videocard. The reality is there are over 100,000 games on steam and an 8gb card will play 99.9 percent of them without issue, and thats being generous to the 8gb is not enough cause because i think it would be a struggle to find 100 games where 8gb memory massively messes up the experience. Somebody buying entry level hardware should have reasonable expectations and should probably count AAA games that released last month out, its really no loss... for every fud like ass creed shadows there are games like slay the spire 2 or hollow knight silksong on the horizon, this fixation on AAA junk is a problem.

Does nobody remember the days when you didn't actually expect your entry level hardware to play the very latest demanding games without issue. Now its shifted to 8gb isn't enough because there are a stack of games you can count on two hands where its a problem... out of 100 thousand games spanning decades. I dont say this as an 8gb card gamer by the way, 4090 here but it was a massive waste of money truth be told, i enjoy far far less demanding games way more than i do the games this thing was designed for.

The real issue as it has been for years is price, Nvidia does not get my vote because they openly fleece the market and they have solely driven the prices up to stupid levels. It just seems that mainstream outlets are starting to ride the 8gb bandwagon when thats really not the issue provided the price is right. I mean think about it, if this card was $150 suddenly 8gb would be no issue at all because the sheer amount of gaming you can do for that price would be astonishing, so i wish they would drill on the price more than the memory.

comments.text:
@jinx20001Exactly, it all  depends on what games you are mostly going to play, whether it's worth it or not. If you are one of those gamers on a budget who mainly plays on older titles, indie games or are hooked on say a MMO, Online shooter or MOBA, then a 8GB GPU will probably be fine and sufficient enough (at least for now). If however you mostly want a budget GPU to play all of the very latest blockbuster AAA titles (and at high settings), then I would take a very good look elsewhere. Especially at a GPU with more than 8GB of VRAM.
However, the straight up fact is right at the moment, all of the top 20 most played games on PC will all run fine on a 8GB 5060.
BTW, just for reference they are: C2 & 2 & Go, Minecraft, Fortnite, R.E.P.O, Roblox, Sims 4, Dota 2, Schedule I, Leagues of Legends, COD MW2, Valarant, Marvel Rivals, PUBG, Overwatch 1 & 2, GTA5 Online, Rocket League, Apex Legends, TCRS: Siege, Baldur's Gate 3 and Helldivers 2.
BTW, I'm in no way promoting manufacturers to still carry on making 8GB GPU's. They really should have moved on well before now, to at least having a minimum of 12GB of VRAM. However, I'm simply stating that there are still quite a lot of gamers out there who are on a budget and where a 8GB GPU is still more than sufficient for thier needs. And I can also understand them not wanting to fork out extra cash on a 12 or 16GB GPU, when all they ever do is play on Roblox and DOTA 2. Where a 8GB GPU is more than sufficient.
